Mount St. Helens is an active volcano located in Skamania County, Washington, in the Pacific Northwest region of the United States. It is part of the Cascade Range, a major mountain range that extends from British Columbia through Washington and Oregon to Northern California. The volcano is known for its explosive eruption in 1980, which caused significant devastation to the surrounding area.

The advanced information about Mount St. Helens includes its naming after the British diplomat Lord St Helens, a friend of explorer George Vancouver, and its inclusion in the Cascade Volcanic Arc, which comprises over 160 active volcanoes. The eruption in 1980 had far-reaching impacts on the surrounding region and the United States as a whole, leading to changes in volcanic monitoring and emergency response protocols.
